Passion: Drive that leads to romance, physical attraction, and sex
Decision/Commitment: the decision that one loves another and the commitment to maintain the love
Identifiable victim effect: People donate more to help a cause when there is an identifiable victim
Compassion for tragedy decreases as the number of lives increases

Bystander effect: Kitty Genovese - 37 who saw murder didn't call the police
The presence of others inhibits helping
The Spotlight Effect: People overestimate the extent to which their actions and appearance are noticed by others
Integrative negotiation: Involves multiple issues, differences in priorities and interests
Successful outcomes involve value creation, not just value claiming
Distributive issues: when you value things in exactly the inverse way as your negotiation partner
Compatible issues: when the same outcome is good for you both
Integrative issues: when you and your partner have different p priorities on different issues, which is almost always the case
Mass psychogenic illness: The collective occurrence of self-reported and or objective symptoms in the absence of an identifiable pathogen
Perspective changes the effects? (how stress is perceived to impact one's health literally describes how it plays out)
Naive realism: The belief that our subjective experience is an objective, unmediated copy of reality
One person's trash is another's treasure
Illusion of transparency: tendency for people to overestimate how much other can see their internal states
Moral reframing hypothesis: reframing a position in terms of the audience's moral values will lead to increased support
Immune Neglect: Tendency of people to overestimate the intensity and duration of their emotions
people neglect that they have an affective immune system
people fail to realize that strong emotions pass relatively quickly
Affective immune system ameliorates bad experiences, and to a lesser extent reduces impact of positive emotions
Misattribution of arousal: Something physical happens to us when around someone that feels like love, so we think we're in love
Imposter Phenomenon: Ironically, success can make you feel like a fake
More common among women and minorities, presumably due to social stigmas

applied to group members whether true or not

Affect everyday life: attributions, evaluations, behavior
